Description: Circular wheel-made pottery lamp with a low body, a central tube and a wide overhanging rim that slopes in towards the centre. The short flat nozzle has a rounded tip and a large oval wick-hole and is blackened with soot. The underside is turned, with a conical surface, with central hole in the middle. Decorated with a black slip in the oil-chamber and on the rim. Fine, light brown fabric with a smooth texture. One third of lamp missing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Nottingham Castle Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Closest parallels for this form are from Athens, though fabric does not look convincing for this origin; another Greek or Cypriot origin is possible (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q38 from Athens; see also Q149 from dated 600-575BC). Fabric and decoration resembles that of East Greek Archaic lamps found at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1971,1224.9; GR 1886,0401.1336; Bristol Museum H2768).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.09) (Phase 3)
